documents.title: that 's all for today !
text: thanks everyone !
until next time .
remember , you can see beverley on tour this spring in the uk .
guardian contributor beverleyknight 21 april 2016 2:07pm i 've just finished my tea , so that means i need another one .
i may even have a cheeky biscuit with it - malted milk of course .
so thank you so much for having a lovely chat with me .
and i 'll see you all on the road soon .
and look out for that album announcement

documents.title: 'marriage has just made me more passionate about people being as happy as i am '
text: david chick asks : do you think marriage has changed how you write music ?
guardian contributor beverleyknight 21 april 2016 2:06pm i think that marriage has just made me more passionate about people being as happy as i am .
i 'm a very happy bev !

documents.title: 'my favourite song of all time is sam cooke 's a change is gon na come '
text: ungainlyblobber asks : hi there !
if i told you every piece of music in human history was about to get wiped from existence but you could save one recording .
what would you save ?
guardian contributor beverleyknight 21 april 2016 2:05pm that is the hardest question in the world , and it 's also brilliant , and my brain is going to hurt for the rest of the day now .
my favourite song of all time is sam cooke 's a change is gon na come .
but it would be a travesty if the world never heard bitches brew by miles davis .
katiemb asks : what do you prefer , touring your own songs and albums or appearing in west end shows ?
what is next for you after this tour ?
guardian contributor beverleyknight 21 april 2016 2:04pm what is next ?

after i finish the tour , and the forthcoming album , i roll straight into rehearsals for the bodyguard in july , but before any of that , look out for me singing a little number at the queen 's 90th birthday celebrations .
i 'm not very busy at all .
ungainlyblobber asks : do you think you would have similar career success if you were starting out at 21 in 2016 rather than the mid 90 's ?
guardian contributor beverleyknight 21 april 2016 2:02pm that is a really interesting question .
and i think as challenging as it was , to be a black female r & b/soul singer , in a britain that was celebrating all things britpop - i came out in the middle of that !
- at least back then i had a chance to develop my craft as an artist .
new artists , to me , do n't have the luxury of time to develop any more .
you need to be a hit now .
oh , you 're not ?
bye !
prince only became the superstar that he is today at album number six , which was purple rain .
just my little nerd reference
jcedwards asks : beverly , brexit : are you in or out ?
guardian contributor beverleyknight 21 april 2016 2:00pm the out brigade has some `` interesting '' characters , dare i say dubious .
having said that , the eu needs reform like yesterday .
david hewitt asks : ca n't wait to see you on tour in june !
how is the album shaping up ?
do we have any idea of release dates and whether we will hear anything from it on the tour ? !
guardian contributor beverleyknight 21 april 2016 1:59pm the album is sounding bloody brilliant , if i may say so myself .
i am so proud of this record , and hold tight for a big announcement about release dates and titles you will absolutely get a sneaky preview of songs when i 'm on the road .
amer hussain asks : hi - i have a 13 year old daughter ( dreamer ) who loves to sing should i encourage or discourage her ?
in my opinion she 's ok but not superstar material guardian contributor beverleyknight 21 april 2016 1:57pm absolutely encourage her to sing .
it 's not everybody 's dream to be up front , centre stage , but singing gives so much joy to yourself and if you 're decent to everybody else !
let her do it because she loves it , and it makes her happy .
tanveer bassan asks : what would you have done differently in your career if you had the chance to go through your life again ?
guardian contributor beverleyknight 21 april 2016 1:56pm i am happy at how my career has gone .
when i look back , even the things that seemed tough at the time , i now realise just were a steep learning curve .
a couple of deals , and business decisions i made were perhaps not the best , but that means now i pay attention to any kind of business proposal that 's put in front of me .
id1519791 asks : what 's you perfect sunday ?

guardian contributor beverleyknight 21 april 2016 1:55pm i love when i have time to go home to wolverhampton , all the family piles round mum 's house for a proper full-on west indian sunday dinner , and then mum makes trifle at the end , but swaps out the cold custard for butterscotch angel delight .
i love watching films on a sunday - a good sunday film would be something like evan almighty , because my mum can watch too .
once mum 's gone to bed then the real film-watching can begin - something like kill bill or american psycho .
fabulous !
goodbyeeurope asks : marmite yay or nay ?
guardian contributor beverleyknight 21 april 2016 1:52pm a massive yes .
i love marmite .
i do n't eat bread much at all , but i will smash to pieces a bit of toast with real butter and marmite on top .
that is a treat .
kara grimes asks : hi !
do you have any little rituals or superstitions you have to do before you go on stage ? ?

guardian contributor beverleyknight 21 april 2016 1:51pm my band and i always gather in my room , the courvoisier gets poured into shot glasses , and everybody downs a shot in one except me , because i always have a cup of tea !
artmod asks : who 's the better harmonica player , bob dylan or kevin spacey ?
guardian contributor beverleyknight 21 april 2016 1:51pm bob dylan just has the edge .
philipphilip99 asks : when bumping into robert plant at the molineux have you ever thought of suggesting a duet ?
guardian contributor beverleyknight 21 april 2016 1:50pm i love planty - i 've got a great of me with him on my phone .
i 've seen him at molineux .
you never know one day that duet might just happen .
and it would probably be something quite bluesy , that 's where we 've got common ground .
sigma66 asks : do n't you wish lewis taylor would make a comeback ?
guardian contributor beverleyknight 21 april 2016 1:49pm yes !
just yes .
terry arnold asks : biggest musical influences ?
if you could choose any renowned songwriter to pen a song for you , who would it be ?
love your voice , strong , sweet and soulful .
looking forward to seeing you live soon .
guardian contributor beverleyknight 21 april 2016 1:49pm prince , sam cooke , aretha , chaka khan .
i grew up with these guys plus a whole army of others .
my ear would always lend itself to anyone who had a great voice .

and there are so many elements of varied vocalists who made their way into my own vocal style - for example , as a child , i always wanted to be able to sing high notes in full voice , and not falsetto voice , the way that chaka khan always does .
so i practised and practised until i could do just that .
songwriters , i 'd love carole king to write something just for me .
she writes such powerful songs from a woman 's point of view , but they always capture everyday experiences in everyday language .
texavery asks : your cover of twist and shout to celebrate 50 years of the release of please please me was absolutely blistering !
did you have to do any special vocal exercises prior to the performance or was it just business as usual ?
guardian contributor beverleyknight 21 april 2016 1:46pm i sang the song the way i heard it in my head .
i wanted to take it back to its isley brothers roots - of course it 's not widely known that twist and shout was actually a cover .
i just wanted to take people to church .
aaron fuller asks : will there be any songs from the various musicals you 've been involved with on the album or tour ?
guardian contributor beverleyknight 21 april 2016 1:45pm i will be giving a nod to my adventures in theatre land on stage !

documents.title: 'i 've had someone burst into tears and then stop and start singing my songs at me , and then burst into tears again '
text: amy avfc lee asks : what is the craziest thing a fan has ever done after meeting you ? !
i think my mum could be top of the list , she has your signature tattooed on her wrist !
guardian contributor beverleyknight 21 april 2016 1:44pm i 've had someone burst into tears and then stop and start singing my songs at me , and then burst into tears again .
they were not very good .
all i could do was give her a hug - i did n't know what else to do !
your mum 's not alone with the tattooing , i 've met a few fans that have done that
montyburns56 asks : i 've got a 12 copy of your debut single flavour of the old skool , is it worth anything ?
guardian contributor beverleyknight 21 april 2016 1:43pm yeah , it 's worth keeping .

documents.title: 'from the earliest age i understood the value of looking after my first instrument , which is my voice '
text: tamsin8 asks : beverley your voice seems to just keep developing and gaining power .
it 's great to see women growing in this way and an aspect of maturity being valued .
how have you trained and adapted your voice over time ?
any tips ?
guardian contributor beverleyknight 21 april 2016 1:43pm from the earliest age i understood the value of looking after my first instrument , which is my voice .
i would always make sure , before i stepped on a stage , and in general , that i was hydrated and had enough sleep .
i practice and practice and practice , especially the correct form of breathing - that 's where so many people go wrong .
and keep myself fit - vocal stamina is absolutely part of having a strong voice that will stand the test of time .
ask gladys knight !
nothing has changed - she 's singing in all the original keys , she 's still crazy .

documents.title: 'it 's always interesting that a fantastic soul artist who happens to be white will garner more attention '
text: raleighstclair asks : will the british music industry ever do right by a black british soul singer ?
with singers from omar , incognito and don-e , through you , terri walker , the late lynden david hall and so on , they seemed to get one shot at a successful album and then nothing .
you are all still making good music and still have the talent , yet do n't seem to get the long-term faith other artists get .
there also seems to be a powerful drive from the industry to water down the sounds in a way a joss stone or amy winehouse never seemed to endure .
is that so ?
many black british singers seem to get greater respect across the pond , too .
is part of the problem with a local fanbase that , on a broader scale , would much prefer an american singer or group than a british one ?
guardian contributor beverleyknight 21 april 2016 1:40pm there 's a lot of truth in what you say .
i would add that my career that my career has gone in a different direction to that of don and terri , because i understood that diversifying was the key to survival .
but crucially i had a team of people , ie my management , who fought alongside me passionately to make sure that i stayed in the game .
it 's never been an easy road being a ) a black artist and b ) a female artist , in the british music industry , or indeed any music industry in the world .
america has way more numbers than we do , so artists can be successful and secure enough in their success that they can put out albums at a rate that is comfortable to them .
america therefore is a lot more tribal in its music scenes because often people are successful within their own genre and do n't have to have mass crossover appeal .
in england , being so much smaller , crossover is so important because the numbers of dedicated soul fans are not enough for you to be able to have a , shall we say , relaxed work rate !

it 's always interesting that a fantastic soul artist who happens to be white will garner more attention , because the underlying marketing truth is that there is way more surprise in a white artist having a voice that would be associated with someone who is black .
it was ever thus .
you can do two things with this information when you first start out .
you can be mad , and increasingly get bitter about it .
or you can understand that this is how it is , and smash the beliefs to bits , jump over the obstacles that are put in your way , and just keep going .
i chose to do the latter .
the point is that , as a black female soul artist , you just have to be even more brilliant than everybody else !

documents.title: 'i could go off on a whole tangent about biscuits '
text: blecca asks : you can only eat one type of biscuit for the rest of your life what biscuit do you go for ?
beverleyknight 21 april 2016 1:33pm malted milk , with the cow on it .
it reminds me of my childhood .
but it must be said that is it rare to find me eating a biscuit .
beverleyknight 21 april 2016 1:33pm oooh , and i quite like oaty ones as well .
i could go off on a whole tangent about biscuits
sceptic101 asks : hi beverley , saw you in the bodyguard and memphis ( twice - and wish i could have seen it more ) , and will be seeing you in concert in june .
do you prefer acting or concerts and why ?
beverleyknight 21 april 2016 1:32pm music will always be my first love .
but i have and always have had a real love of acting .
as a child i was never off the stage , performing in one musical or play after another , all the way through to my university years .
that only ended when my music career began , back in 1994 .
i hope in the future i 'll be able to have a duality in my career , where i have opportunities to act as much as i have to sing .
i love the fact that i 'm part of an ensemble in musicals - it 's a wonderful thing to share the stage with varied talents .
there 's a great feeling you get when you 're part of a number which involves the full cast .
it 's not dissimilar to being in the audience at a really great concert , where you all have the same feeling at the same time .
david christopher mckenna asks : beverley i always play your music at work and the younger people always ask who it is .
every generation lives your voice , but what i want to ask is : do you like anita baker ?
and have you ever wanted to cover any of her songs ?
beverleyknight 21 april 2016 1:29pm i love anita baker .
i could n't even begin to try and cover one of her songs because she has a very distinct style in her own singing - she has the same kind of swooping melodic interpretation that billie holiday had .
you 're either born with it or not .
it 's not how i sing , and i would much prefer to just listen to her interpret her own songs , rather than encroach on a style that is not mine .
when i hear her , i hear her songs - her songs and her voice are inextricably linked , for me , which would always make it difficult to approach for a cover .

documents.title: 'as long as humans open their mouths , there will be duff notes ! '
text: hokeycokeyfreedom33 asks : having a wonderful soulful voice like yours , at what age did you first realise most folk ca n't sing , and i must add is there a cure for the following illness that follows the belief they can .
please help and all the best on the new album .
beverleyknight 21 april 2016 1:26pm i did n't realise until i went to school , as i grew up with a school where everybody sang , and well !
i could n't understand when people would literally only sing one note no matter where the melody went - my brain ca n't deal with it .
i still ca n't .
beverleyknight 21 april 2016 1:27pm as long as humans open their mouths , there will be duff notes !
and as long as there is a shower , and a hairbrush to sing into , people will believe that they are the greatest singer on earth .
ringolorenzo asks : greetings from a fellow midlander bev !
you 've always shown the gay community a lot of support , and we appreciate it .
what draws you to the lgbt struggle , given that many straight celebrities ignore a lot of the issues surrounding homophobia and gay rights ?
beverleyknight 21 april 2016 1:25pm i do n't like prejudice , of any kind .
it 's even more heinous when those who try to fight back are further ridiculed .

so it takes someone from the majority to stand with the minority , to say : these are my friends , they 're just like me , they have a different sexual orientation , and why should that matter in any way shape or form ?
on a personal level , i stood from the sidelines and watched my dear friend go through the everyday challenges of being a black gay man .
there were certain things i could n't do to help , but what i could do was stand by his side , and say i 'm with you no matter what .
from the earliest age i was aware that i was not part of the majority .
i was one of two black girls in my junior school .
while i was not a victim of terrible systematic bullying , there were isolated incidents .
and in my career , i do n't know if it 's direct racism so much as people expecting a certain stereotype from you , and that has been a hindrance in my career .
i just believe people should be left to love who they love , and lead their own lives as they see fit .

darrell hooper asks : hi beverley , i am a huge fan of all your music and have been for years ( we have seen you in concert several times down south and up north and even in the bodyguard - proper fantastic ) - i should probably be on the payroll , as i am always telling everyone about your voice and that you should be properly recognised as a huge international star and that you are probably the best singer in the world ( i 'm not biased at all haha ) - we have booked vip tickets to meet you at bridgewater hall on the 28th of may ( and ca n't wait - we have centre front row tickets too - i booked very early haha ) - can i ask you one very important question i know its not your song , but will you be singing one more try ( old george michael song ) at the show ?
- i absolutely love your version of this song ( porchester hall recording ) and is one of my personal favourites , i think george michael would agree it is better than his too .
thanks in advance of your answer and really looking forward to seeing you in may beverleyknight 21 april 2016 1:20pm george michael 's version has a resonance which you just ca n't copy .
but i 'm glad you like mine , and see you on the 28th !
liam quane asks : my mum : rita , is an incredibly huge fan of yours .
you 're her favorite singer and an artist whom she personally thinks is underrated regardless of success ; it would never be enough .
can you say hi ?
also , apparently you were in a film in 2005 called premonition , is this true and if so what was it like acting on a film set ?
beverleyknight 21 april 2016 1:19pm i was n't in the film premonition , but your mum rita sounds lovely and thank you so much for her kind words !
jcedwards asks : if approached , would you do a collaboration with stormzy ?
beverleyknight 21 april 2016 1:18pm yeah i would !
why not ?

it 's more what he represents than anything - he 's got so much fun in his delivery , and i love how along with krept & konan , skepta and people like that he 's at the forefront of a wave of really great crossover urban acts .
jcedwards asks : apart from prince , who would be your dream producer to work with ?
beverleyknight 21 april 2016 1:17pm i have several !
if i was doing a straight up funk track , it would have to be mark ronson .

if i was going in a more r & b soulful direction i 'd like to pull dallas austin out of retirement , waterfalls and all that if i wanted to go leftfield and shock you all , i 'd phone up nigel godrich .
in your face !

documents.title: 'black lives matter had a bearing on the material i 've written , but not exclusively '
text: rgemmell asks : i know you recorded the new album in memphis and previously starred in the west end musical about the city .
given the nature of that story , were race relations on your mind when writing the new album ?
beverleyknight 21 april 2016 1:15pm yes , absolutely .
memphis wears its musical history very proudly but also bears many of the scars of its past .

you can see the evidence of what it must have been like to like under jim crow all around you - for example , most of south memphis is desperately poor and overwhelmingly black , and seems to have been abandoned by any kind of regeneration .
of course in the heart of downtown sits the national civil rights museum , the exterior of the building is the lorraine hotel where dr martin luther king jr was shot dead .

there are lots of murals painted in and around the downtown area - the most popular de the march that the memphian sanitation workers went on , when they held up placards that simply stated i am a man .

god , when i just thought about that i got goosebumps it seemed to amplify the current racial tension that is all over the united states , with police shootings and deaths in custody , and the black lives matter campaign .
all those things had a bearing on the material i 've written , but not exclusively .
the songs are not so much political as they are social - i 'm glass half full , so i try to write from a standpoint of hope .
paul culshaw asks : as this album was recorded in memphis , is this a return to music city soul ' in terms of album style ?
beverleyknight 21 april 2016 1:11pm yes , it 's just moving three hours down the road !
to a completely different music city .
it still has that real live earthy soul sound , but the roots are very different from the sound of music city soul , which was recorded in nashville , which is the home of country .
and the sound of that album reflected the heart of nashville .
being of west indian origin , you could n't escape country music - my parents ' generation play country all .
the .
time .
i did n't get it as a child !
i really appreciated the strength of the writing as an adult when i embarked on writing songs myself .
paul culshaw asks : if you could one more single from your back catalogue that you think would have been an amazing single , what would it be and why ?
for me its black butta ' or breakout ' - both sure-fire no.1 's i felt !
x beverleyknight 21 april 2016 1:07pm i was lucky enough to have the big bangers as singles .
it 's difficult when you 're the artist and you 're faced with a huge back catalogue , to think what else would have been a good single i think my song damn would have been a nice groove ballad .
the simplicity of the chorus and the lyric would have made it a song that anyone could have got into .
everyone has that person that they know is rubbish for them but they just ca n't leave them alone - that 's what the song 's about .
and black butta 's the only other one .
and further : as you are widely known for being the voice ' of female soul singers in the uk- is being a mentor or coach on a show such as the voice ' something that interests you or not ?
beverleyknight 21 april 2016 1:08pm mentoring is a wonderful thing .
just not sure about doing it live in front of a bank of tv cameras .
i do n't think you can mentor someone adequately in the space of a few minutes .
i 'd prefer to do it over a long period of time and away from any camera .

documents.title: post your questions for beverley knight
text: beverley knight 's first wave of fame came with her music career , which took in edgy british r & b alongside mainstream pop , on hits like shoulda woulda coulda and greatest day .
her prowess earned her an mbe , and even more impressively , a mastermind trophy for her knowledge of prince .
but there 's also her newfound theatre career , which began with the lead in the bodyguard in 2013 , a role she 's returning to in july .
she 's since played grizabella in cats , and felicia in memphis , for which she was nominated for an olivier award .
the guardian 's michael billington praised her charisma and power in a four-star review .
she 's touring in may ahead of a new album , and joins us on thursday 21 april to answer your questions in a live webchat , from 1pm bst onwards .
post them in the comments below , and she 'll answer as many as possible .
